awd_titl_txt: Second-Order Variational Analysis and Its Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to develop efficient tools of mathematical analysis to investigate challenging problems arising in optimization, systems control, and other fields of applied mathematics unified under the name of variational analysis. This new form of analysis employs generalized differential calculus when the standard calculus methods are not available. The main motivation for developing these tools of analysis is to solve a number of practical problems of engineering, mechanics, and behavioral sciences. Results of this project arm researchers and practitioners with new machinery that make it possible to solve problems that provide valuable insight to practical issues.

This project focuses on second-order variational analysis, which has been largely underinvestigated from both viewpoints of theoretical studies and practical applications.  It carries out a systematic development of generalized differential tools of second-order analysis, with applications to the design and justification of numerical algorithms in nonsmooth optimization and related areas. Among other directions of research, the project applies second-order variational analysis to broad classes of finite-dimensional and infinite-dimensional variational systems, which go far beyond optimization and optimal control. Results will be beneficial to both applied mathematics and applied science communities.

por.por_cntn:
During the reporting period, the main attention of the PI and his team was addressed developing optimal control theory for the so-called sweeping (Moreau) processes. Dynamical systems of this type have been known and well investigated over the years being motivated by various models arising in problems of elastoplasticity, hysteresis, economics, and other applied sciences. However, optimal control problems for them have been formulated quite recently. The PI and his collaborators have made significant contributions to developing optimal control theory for various classes of sweeping processes. New optimality conditions for such challenging control systems were obtained during this reporting period by developing qualitative and quantitative aspects of the method of discrete approximations. Another important ingredient of the developed approach is the broad usage of first-order and mainly second-order generalized differentiation of variational analysis, which perfectly fits the framework of controlled sweeping processes. The obtained results in this vein are of undoubted importance for applications to practical models in mechanics, traffic equilibria, robotics, socioeconomics, etc., which were given during the performance of the project research.

Besides applications to controlled sweeping processes, the advanced machinery of second-order variational analysis was strongly developed during the life of this award for its own intellectual merit and due to novel applications to various classes of optimization problems, equilibria systems, stability and sensitivity analysis, etc. The established methods and results of second-order variational analysis and generalized differentiation were highly instrumental to achieve both theoretical and numerical advances in these areas with a variety of applications, including the recent ones to behavioral sciences. All of this constitutes the intellectual merit of the project research.

The achieved finding and results were published in the highest-ranked journal sin mathematics and its applications. During the life of this award, eight PhD students, who participated in the project research, defended their doctoral dissertations and started to work in academy and industry.
